abstracts.cdata!:
The General Education Project for Sri
            Lanka was rated satisfactory. The project achieved most of
            its objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            modest, sustainability is likely, and the performance of
            both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, organized,
            long-term communication between ministries and regional
            offices clearly improves implementation outcome. Second,
            task manager diligence, knowledge, and implementation
            orientation can significantly influence project outcomes.
            Third, insufficient attention may be paid to the
            instructional consequences of building designs. Projects
            should study noise and heat levels in school rooms of
            different types relative to instructional outcomes. Fourth,
            remote schools are more likely to have cumulative problems,
            including low-quality construction. More support in time and
            effort should be made to supervise those sites. Finally,
            instructional materials, particularly for science, may stay
            unused until expertise and a real motive for using them
            exists. In addition to a clear rationale for choosing each
            item, training must be provided in their use and teacher
            supervision must include the use of instructional aids.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the General Education
            Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been partially successful, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, there is a need for the Government to
            address the lengthy period required to staff new project
            implementation units. Second, clearer follow-up procedures
            to address key policy recommendations of the National
            Education Commission and studies need to be
            institutionalized. Third, the membership of tender
            committees needs to be further standardized by MEHE to
            reduce the numerous and lengthy reviews and speed up the
            procurement process. Fourth, joint efforts by GOSL and IDA
            to standardize the content of progress reports should be
            continued. Fifth, project performance and sustainability
            increased when the operational unit responsible for
            continuation of the activities was given implementation
            responsibilities. Sixth, future investments in the education
            sector should be based on clearly defined criteria and
            measures to assess the impact of these inputs should be
            developed. Finally, when IDA identifies a task manager
            appropriately and gives the task manager sufficient
            authority and resources to address policy and implementation
            issues, increased consistency occurs and the implementation
            of a project improves.

docna.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - General Education Project :
            Credit 2072 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - General Education
            Project : Credit 2072 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the General Education
            Project are: (a) to increase the effectiveness of the school
            system, by upgrading physical facilities and increasing the
            supply of material inputs; (b) to improve operational
            efficiency through better management and supervision; (c) to
            reduce large regional and local disparities in the quality
            of schools; (d) to support decentralization of the school
            system, and facilitate the transition to Provincial
            Councils; (e) to strengthen educational planning capability;
            and (f) to begin the process of adjusting the balance
            between various types of education and training - to bring
            them more closely in line with employment opportunities and
            manpower requirements. The project consists of the following
            three main elements: (a) physical facilities, an
            infrastucture component; (b) management strengthening; and
            (c) education policy development.
